In general, higher confidence means wider intervals (Fig.\ \@ref(fig:CIWidthsMany)), since wider intervals are needed to be *more* certain that the interval contains the value of ${p}$ that produced the value of $\hat{p}$.


```{r CIWidthsMany, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2.3, fig.width=6.5, fig.cap="To have greater confidence that the interval straddles the value of the population proportion, the interval needs to be wider, for any given sample size", fig.align="center", out.width='70%'}
phat <- 0.5
n <- 25

sep <- sqrt( phat*(1 - phat) / n )
levels <- c(0.90, 0.95, 0.99, 0.997)
zs <- qnorm( 1 - (1 - levels) / 2)
mes <- sep * zs

par( mar = c(4.0, 5, 2, 1) + 0.1)
plot( x = c(0, 1),
      y = c(0, 1), 
      axes = FALSE, 
      xlab = "Sample proportions",
      ylab = "", 
      main = "Greater confidence needs wider intervals", 
      type = "n")
axis(side = 1)
abline(v = phat)


### Label the confidence level on the left
arrows(phat - mes[1], 0.9,    
       phat + mes[1], 0.9,    
       code = 3, 
       angle = 90, 
       length = 0.1,
       col = ifelse( knitr::is_latex_output(), "black", "blue"), 
       lwd = 2, 
       ylim = c(0, 0.35))
text(0.21, 0.9,
     "90% CI", 
     cex = 0.95)

arrows(phat - mes[2], 0.6, 
       phat + mes[2], 0.6, 
       code = 3,
       angle = 90,		
       length = 0.1,
       col = ifelse( knitr::is_latex_output(), "black", "blue"), 
       lwd = 2,
       ylim = c(0, 0.35))
text(0.19, 0.6, 
     "95% CI", 
     cex = 0.9)

arrows(phat - mes[3], 0.3, 
       phat + mes[3], 0.3, 
       code = 3, 
       angle = 90, 
       length = 0.1,
       col = ifelse( knitr::is_latex_output(), "black", "blue"), 
       lwd = 2, 
       ylim = c(0, 0.35))
text(0.17, 0.3,
     "99% CI", 
     cex = 0.9)
```
